orbital.label: Earth's orbital changes
orbital.title: Is it the Earth's orbit?
orbital.sub: No. Although changes in Earth's orbit have been linked to climate change in the past, the effect over the last 125 years is small.

solar.label: Solar temperature
solar.title: Is it the sun?
solar.sub: No. The sun's temperature varies over decades and centuries. But these changes have had little effect on our climate.

volcanic.label: Volcanic activity
volcanic.title: Is it volcanoes?
volcanic.sub: No. Erupting volcanoes have a short-term cooling effect.

land_use.label: Land use
land_use.title: Is it land use?
land_use.sub: Actually, no. When forests are cleared, the land underneath reflects more sunlight than the darker trees. This light bounces off Earth's surface, causing the planet to cool a little.

aerosols.label: Aerosols
aerosols.title: Is aerosol pollution?
aerosols.sub: No. Some pollutants cool the atmosphere, like sulfate aerosols from coal-burning which offset some of the warming. (Unfortunately, they also cause acid rain.)

ghgs.label: Greenhouse gases
ghgs.title: Is it greenhouse gases?
ghgs.sub: Yes! The rise in heat-trapping greenhouse gases is the only factor that matches the worldâ€™s warming since 1880.
